review.title: Cross-lingual Annotation Projection for Semantic Roles
review.abstract: This article considers the task of automatically inducing role-semantic annotations in the FrameNet paradigm for new languages. We propose a general framework that is based on annotation projection, phrased as a graph optimization problem. It is relatively inexpensive and has the potential to reduce the human effort involved in creating role-semantic resources. Within this framework, we present projection models that exploit lexical and syntactic information. We provide an experimental evaluation on an English-German parallel corpus which demonstrates the feasibility of inducing high-precision German semantic role annotation both for manually and automatically annotated English data.

sections.heading: 2.3 Evaluation
sections.text: In fact, the annotations for each language are made independently of each other, so they can be used to estimate the degree of semantic parallelism between the two languages. We measure parallelism with precision and recollection, treating German annotations as the gold standard. This rating scheme directly measures the applicability of English as the source language for annotations. Less than 100% recall means that the target language has frames or roles that are not available in English, and cannot be replaced by annotations. Conversely, imperfect precision indicates that there are English frames or roles that produce erroneous annotations in the target language. Frames and roles are counted when they occur in both halves, regardless of their role.

sections.heading: 3. Modeling Semantic Role Projection with Semantic Alignments
sections.text: Most previous work on projection relies on word alignments to transfer annotations between languages. However, this is not surprising, since annotations of interest are often defined at the word level (e.g. parts of words, sense of words, or dependencies) and rarely comprise more than one character. In contrast, semantic roles can cover sentence components of any length and simply use word alignments for projection, which is likely to lead to incorrect role alignments. sections.heading: 3.3.1 Alignments as Perfect Matchings
sections.text: First, we look at the most restrictive case, where each constituent has exactly one adjacent alignment edge, and vice versa. Semantic alignments with this property can be considered as bijective functions: each source constituent is assigned to a target constituent, and vice versa. The resulting two-part graphs are roughly perfect matches. An example of perfect two-part matching is given in Figure 3a. Note that the target page contains two nodes called (e), an abbreviation for "empty" nodes. Since second sentences often differ in size, the resulting graph partitions will also have different sizes. In such cases, we will insert empty nodes in the smaller partition to allow a perfect match. Empty nodes will be assigned to all other nodes with a similarity of zero.

sections.heading: 3.3.2 Alignments as Edge Covers
sections.text: Next, we look at edge lids, a generalization of perfect matches. Edge lids are split graphs in which each source and each target component is adjacent to at least one edge (see source nodes (2) and target nodes (4)). Edge lids impose weaker match assumptions than perfect matches because they allow for one-to-many match between components in both directions.10 Thus, in theory, edge lids have a higher chance of delivering a correct role projection than perfect matches when the syntactical structures of source and target sentences are different. They are also better able to deal with situations in which semantic roles are assigned to more than one component in one of the languages (see source nodes (3) and (4), labeled with role 2).

sections.heading: 3.3.3 Total Alignments
sections.text: The last family of allowable alignments we are looking at are total alignments. Since each source constituent is associated with an arbitrary number of source constituents here (i.e. the alignments form a total function on the source node), total alignments do not impose any constraints on the target nodes, which can therefore be associated with any number of source constitution nodes, including none. Total alignments are the most generous alignment class. Unlike perfect matchings and edge caps, components cannot be aligned in the target set. Can10 total alignments. sections.heading: 3.4 Noise Reduction
sections.text: As discussed in Section 2, noise elimination techniques are an integral part of projection architectures. Although our constitution-based model will not be overly sensitive to noise - we expect the syntactic information to compensate for alignment errors - the word-based model will be more error-prone as it relies solely on automatically obtained alignments for transferring semantic roles. Below, we present three filter techniques that correct or reject erroneous projections.

sections.heading: 3.4.1 Filling-the-gaps
sections.text: According to our definition of the projection in Equation (5), the span of a projected role r corresponds to the union of all target units aligned to source units labeled with r. This definition is sufficient for constitution-based projection models in which roles rarely comprise more than one component, but for word-based models in which roles typically comprise multiple source units (i.e. words) lead to many incorrect alignments. Due to errors and gaps in word alignment, the target span of a role will often be a disjointed set of words. We can repair non-contiguous predictions in which the first and last word were correctly projected by applying simple heuristics that fill the gaps in a target role span. sections.heading: 3.4.2 Word Filtering
sections.text: This technique removes words that form a two sentence before being projected according to certain criteria. In our experiments, we apply two intuitive instances of word filtering: the first removes non-substantive words, i.e. all words that are not adjectives, adverbs, verbs or nouns, from the original sentence and target sentence, since alignments for non-substantive words are known to be unreliable and can negatively affect similarity calculations; the second removes all words that are not aligned in the output of automatic word alignment; both filters aim to distinguish real word alignments from words and speed up the calculation of semantic alignments.

sections.heading: 3.4.3 Argument Filtering
sections.text: Previous work in the field of flat semantic parsing has shown that not all nodes in a tree are equally likely to be semantic roles for a given predicate (Xue & Palmer, 2004). Indeed, assuming a perfect parse, there is a "set of probable arguments" to which almost all semantic roles should be assigned. This set of probable arguments includes all the components that are a child of any ancestor of the predicate, provided (a) they do not master the predicate itself and (b) there is no sentence boundary between a constituency and its predicate. This definition includes extensive dependencies such as control constructions for verbs or support constructions for nouns and can be expanded to accommodate coordination. We apply this filter to reduce the size of the target tree. In the example in Figure 4, all tree nodes except the S and NP are removed.

sections.heading: 3.5 Discussion
sections.text: We have presented a framework for the bilingual projection of semantic roles based on the notion of semantic alignment errors. We have discussed two broad instances of the framework, namely word-based and constituent-based models. In the latter case, we operationalize the search for optimal semantic alignment as a problem of graph optimization. Specifically, each two-sentence is conceptualized as a two-part graph. Its nodes correspond to the syntactic components of the second sentence and its weighted edges of lingual similarity between components. Assumptions of semantic agreement between languages are formalized as constraints on the graph structure. We have also discussed three families of constraints. Perfect correspondence forces the similarities between English and German components to be bijective.

sections.heading: 4. Experiments
sections.text: We will now describe our assessment of the framework developed in Section 3. We will present two experiments that both take into account the projection of semantic roles from English sentences onto their German translations and rate them against the annotation of German gold standard roles. Experiment 1 uses gold standard data for both syntactical and semantic annotations. This "oracle setting" evaluates the potential of role projection on its own, separating errors due to translational divergences and our modelling assumptions from those resulting from pre-processing (e.g. parsing and automatic alignment). Experiment 2 examines a more practical setting that uses automatic tools for syntactic and semantic parsing, thus approximating the conditions of large-scale role projection on parallel corpora.

sections.text: All models were evaluated using the parallel corpus described in section 2, which was randomly mixed and divided into a development group and a test group (each containing 50% of the data).Table 5 indicates the number of tokens, sentences, frames and arguments in the development and test set for English and German. Word alignments were calculated using the GIZA + + toolkit (Och & Ney, 2003).We used the entire English-German Europarl bittext as training data to induce alignments for both directions (source-target, target-source) with the default settings GIZA + +. According to common machine translation practice, alignments were symmetrized using the interface heuristics (Koehn, Och, & Marcu, 2003), which is known to lead to highly precise word alignments.

sections.heading: 4.1.2 Method
sections.text: We implemented the four models shown in Table 4 alone and with the filtering techniques introduced in Section 3.4, resulting in a total of sixteen models, all of which were evaluated on the basis of the development set. Results for the most powerful models were then validated on the test set. We found that the practical runtime of our experiment was dominated by input-output XML processing, not by the optimization problem itself. In both experiments, constituent-based models were compared with the word-based model that we treat as the basic model. The latter model is relatively simple: the projection is based exclusively on word alignment, does not require syntactic analysis, and has a linear time complexity, making it a good point of comparison for models that take linguistic knowledge into account.

sections.heading: 4.1.3 Evaluation Measure
sections.text: We measure model performance using the terms Precision, Recall, and F1 in the "Exact Match" condition, i.e. both the label and the range of the projected English role must match the role of the German gold standard to be considered truly positive. We also assess whether performance differences are statistically significant by using layer mixtures (Noreen, 1989), an example of approximation-free randomization testing (see Yeh, 2000, for a discussion).11 Whenever we discuss changes in F1, we refer to absolute (not relative) differences.

sections.heading: 4.1.4 Upper Bound
sections.text: Our annotation study (see Table 2, Section 2.2) achieved an interannotator match of 0.84 in the chip-match condition (note the same rolls with the same margin), which can be considered an appropriate upper limit for the performance of an automatic semantic role marking system within a language. It is more difficult to set an upper limit for the projection task since, in addition to the interannotator agreement, we must take into account the effect of bilingual divergence. Our annotation study provided an estimate of the former, but not the latter. In the absence of a method for measuring bilingual match on chip matches, we use the monolingual chip match as the upper limit for our projection experiments. sections.heading: 4.3 Experiment 2: Projection with Automatic Roles
sections.text: In this experiment, we evaluate our projection models in a more realistic environment and use automatic tools for syntactic and semantic parsing.

sections.heading: 4.3.1 Preprocessing
sections.text: For this experiment, we used the uncorrected syntactical analysis of the bilingual corpus provided by Collins' (1997) and Dubey's (2005) parsers (see Section 2.1). We automatically assigned their parser based on their "standard features" and not based on the "extended" set, which is based on PropBank and would have required a PropBank analysis of the entire FrameNet corpus. We applied the flat semantic parser to the English side of our parallel corpus (Release 1.2) to obtain semantic roles and treat the frames as gives.14 The task is to locate the frame elements in a sentence and find the correct name for a particular FrameNet element.

In recent years, interest has grown in parallel corpora for multilingual and cross-lingual natural language processing. Beyond machine translation, parallel corpora can be exploited to relieve the effort involved in creating annotations for new languages. One important paradigm, annotation projection, creates new monolingual resources by transferring annotations from English (or other resource-rich languages) onto resource-scarce languages through the use of word alignments. The resulting (noisy) annotations can be then used in conjunction with robust learning algorithms to obtain NLP tools such as taggers and chunkers relatively cheaply. The projection approach has been successfully used to transfer a wide range of linguistic annotations between languages. Examples include parts of speech (Yarowsky et al., 2001; Hi & Hwa, 2005), chunks (Yarowsky et al., 2001), dependencies (Hwa et al., 2002), word senses (Diab & Resnik, 2002; Bentivogli & Pianta, 2005), information extraction markup (Riloff, Schafer, & Yarowsky, 2002), coreference chains (Postolache, Cristea, & Orasan, 2006), temporal information (Spreyer & Frank, 2008), and LFG f-structures (Tokarczyk & Frank, 2009). An important assumption underlying annotation projection is that linguistic analyses in one language will be also valid in another language. It is however unrealistic to expect any two languages, even of the same family, to be in perfect correspondence. There are many well-studied systematic differences across languages often referred to as translational divergences (van Leuven-Zwart, 1989; Dorr, 1995). These can be structural, where the same semantic content in the source and in the target language can be realized using different structures, or semantic, where the content itself undergoes a change in translation. Translational divergences (in conjunction with poor alignments) are a major stumbling block towards achieving accurate projections. Yarowsky and Ngai (2001) find that parts of speech that are transferred directly from English onto French contain considerable noise, even in cases where inaccurate automatic alignments have been manually corrected (accuracies vary between 69% and 78% depending on tagset granularity).

The widely used Kappa statistic is not directly applicable to our task as it requires a fixed set of items to be classified into a fixed set of categories. In our case, however, there are no fixed items, since the span for the frame elements can have any length. In addition, the categories (i.e., frames and roles) are predicate-specific, and vary from item to item (for a discussion of this issue, see also the work of Miltsakaki et al., 2004). Instead, we compute three different agreement measures defined as: the ratio of common frames between two sentences (Frame Match), the ratio of common roles (Role Match), and the ratio of roles with identical spans (Span Match). As shown in Table 2, annotators tend to agree in frame assignment; disagreements are mainly due to fuzzy distinctions between closely related frames (e.g., between Awareness and Certainty). Annotators also agree on what roles to assign and on identifying role spans. Overall, we obtain high agreement for all aspects of the annotation, which indicates that the task is well-defined. Using a phrase-based SMT system, they heuristically assemble target role spans out of phrase translations, defining phrase similarity in terms of translation probability. Their method occupies a middle ground between word-based projection and constituent-based projection. Despite individual differences, most approaches formalize word alignment as a minimumweight matching problem, where each pair of words in a bi-sentence is associated with a score representing the desirability of that pair. The alignment for the bi-sentence is the highest scoring matching under some constraints, for example that matchings must be oneto-one. (2005) examine solely perfect matchings and Matusov et al. (2004) only edge covers. A number of studies have addressed the constituent alignment problem in the context of extracting of translation patterns (Kaji, Kida, & Morimoto, 1992; Imamura, 2001). However, most approaches only search for pairs of constituents which are perfectly word aligned, an infeasible strategy when alignments are obtained automatically. Other work focuses on the constituent alignment problem, but uses greedy search techniques that are not guaranteed to find an optimal solution (Matsumoto, Ishimoto, & Utsuro, 1993; Yamamoto & Matsumoto, 2000). A similar approach is described in a paper by Collins, Koehn, and Kučerová (2005); however, the rules are manually specified and the constituent alignment step reduces to inspection of the source-target sentence pairs.

Both filters are independent of the language pair and make only weak assumptions about the underlying linguistic representations in question. The choice of the best filter depends on the goals of projection. Removing non-aligned words is relatively conservative and tends to balance precision and recall. In contrast, the more aggressive filtering of non-arguments yields projections with high precision and low recall. Arguably, for training shallow semantic parsers on the target language (Johansson & Nugues, 2006), it is more desirable to have access to high-quality projections. However, there is a number of options for increasing precision subsequent to projection that we have not explored in this article. One fully automatic possibility is generalization over multiple occurrences of the same predicate to detect and remove suspicious projection instances, e.g. following the work by Dickinson and Lee (2008). Bracketing information can be acquired in an unsupervised fashion (Geertzen, 2003).

As mentioned earlier, our models are also relevant for machine translation and could be used for the reordering of constituents. Our results indicate that syntactic knowledge on the target side plays an important role in projecting annotations with longer spans. Unfortunately, for many languages there are no broad-coverage parsers available. However, it may not be necessary to obtain complete parses for the semantic role projection task. Two types of syntactic information are especially valuable here: bracketing information (which guides projection towards linguistically plausible role spans) and knowledge about the arguments of sentence predicates. Bracketing information can be acquired in an unsupervised fashion (Geertzen, 2003). Argument structure information could be obtained from dependency parsers (e.g., McDonald, 2006) or partial parsers that are able to identify predicate-argument relations (e.g., Hacioglu, 2004). Another interesting direction concerns the combination of longer phrases, like those provided by phrase-based SMT systems, with constituent information obtained from the output of a parser or chunker. The experiments presented in this article made use of a simple semantic similarity measure based on word alignment. A more sophisticated approach could have combined the alignment scores with information provided in a bilingual dictionary. metadata.abstractText: This article considers the task of automatically inducing role-semantic annotations in the FrameNet paradigm for new languages. We propose a general framework that is based on annotation projection, phrased as a graph optimization problem. It is relatively inexpensive and has the potential to reduce the human effort involved in creating role-semantic resources. Within this framework, we present projection models that exploit lexical and syntactic information. We provide an experimental evaluation on an English-German parallel corpus which demonstrates the feasibility of inducing high-precision German semantic role annotation both for manually and automatically annotated English data.
